reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: I’ve spent 60-plus years investing in businesses I understand – consumer staples, insurance, railroads and simple industrials. Microsoft operates in complex enterprise software and cloud computing, outside my knitting. I don’t fully grasp the nuances of SaaS economics or cloud margin dynamics, so right off the bat it fails my #1 test: “Risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing.”

2. Competitive Moat: On the surface, Microsoft shows strong operating margins near 72%, hinting at some pricing power in its cloud and Office franchises. But over the last ten years only 0 of 10 periods saw ROE above 15%, and earnings growth has been inconsistent. Compare that to Coca-Cola’s enduring brand or See’s Candies’ pricing power – their economics are clear and reliable. Microsoft’s advantage feels less durable.

3. Management Quality: Satya Nadella has done a fine job steering the ship, but recent common stock issuances dilute existing owners, and the company’s minimal dividend policy suggests they’re hoarding cash rather than returning it to shareholders. I prefer managers who think and act like owners – reinvesting at high returns or boldly buying back stock when it’s cheap.

4. Financial Health and Consistency: A 6.3% ROE and 1.23 debt-to-equity ratio concern me. Low returns on invested capital (2.8%) and erratic earnings growth (-1.3% over ten periods) signal a business that can’t consistently earn its cost of capital. My ideal business throws off predictable, growing owner earnings – like GEICO or BNSF – and Microsoft isn’t delivering that.

5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: Your three-stage DCF pegs intrinsic value at roughly $60,500 per share, with a conservative haircut bringing it to $51,400. That implies the stock is trading over 80% above intrinsic value (negative margin of safety of -84.7%). I don’t want to overpay. As I’ve said, “Price is what you pay; value is what you get.” At today’s level, there’s no margin for error.

6. Long-Term Prospects and Red Flags: Technology shifts faster than soda brands. Ten-year consistency matters, and Microsoft’s lack thereof exposes it to competitive and execution risk. I prefer businesses that will flourish a century from now – not merely ride the latest cloud wave.

7. Opportunity Cost: I’d rather deploy capital into proven, simple franchises I understand – Coca-Cola’s moat, Apple’s consumer ecosystem, See’s Candies’ pricing power – at fair valuations than gamble on a complex software giant at a lofty price.

Conclusion: Microsoft fails the circle of competence test, sports mediocre returns on equity, inconsistent earnings, and trades far above my estimate of intrinsic value. I’ll pass and remain on the sidelines.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 6.3%; High debt to equity ratio of 1.2; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -1.3% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 73.3%) suggest some competitive advantage

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (1.4%, 5y), Stage 2 (0.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
